repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency District
            Heating Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of the project was
            satisfactory, for, despite implementation delays, most of
            the physical objectives were met, and, financial and
            institutional objectives are progressing. The key lessons
            call, primarily, for flexibility in project design,
            particularly for emergency operations, for, although a
            flexible approach was followed in financing certain items,
            allowing a quick response to emergency needs, there were
            nonetheless, difficulties in securing donor financing, which
            caused implementation delays in the second phase of the
            project, with further delays in disbursements of the Trust
            fund Credit, also because of lack of available financing.
            This indicates that, in the absence of co-financing
            commitments, project components would better remain
            independent, and viable on their own, considering the
            importance of a timely closure in an emergency project.
            Advance mechanisms for emergency operations are critical, as
            demonstrated by the difficulties experienced in handling
            transfers, and adjustment disbursements, through the Project
            Start-Up Advances. It is suggested, an extended Project
            Preparation Facility could be useful, and thus avoid
            difficulties encountered in project transfers of funds.
            Attention should be given to the essential role of a strong
            project unit within the beneficiary, for, its effective
            contribution will prod success, through adequate support and autonomy.

repnme.cdata!:
Bosnia and Herzegovina - Emergency District
            Heating Reconstruction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Emergency District
            Heating Reconstruction Project are to: 1) restore district
            heating service in Sarajevo as soon as possible by
            reconstructing both the district heat supply system as well
            as by reconstructing building internal heating
            installations; 2) enable Bosnia and Herzegovina to
            potentially reduce its gas consumption through fuel
            switching by Toplane-Sarajevo from gas to fuel oil, which
            will enhance the country's strategically important
            security of energy supply; 3) strengthen
            Toplane-Sarajevo's institutional capacity; and 4)
            initiate network improvements. The project will enhance
            energy efficiency and energy conservation and reduce
            environmental pollution by enabling disconnection of about
            34,000 flats in Sarajevo from self-made gas connections. The
            project consists of the following major components: 1) a
            technical assistance component, especially needed for: (a)
            project management; (b) engineering; (c) financial and
            commercial management; and (d) system planning; and 2) a
            reconstruction component which includes: (a) boilers; (b)
            distribution network; (c) substations; (d) remote control
            center; (e) internal building installations; and (f)
            metering. In Sarajevo, the major components will be: 1)
            technical assistance which will be used for project
            management, including an engineering survey and assessment,
            and for staff training, master plan and tariff studies; and
            2) investments for the reconstruction all of parts of the
            district heating network, including building internals. In
            Banja Luka, technical assitance will be used for project
            preparation (engineering survey and assessment) only.
